2d35b705ad4c.description: Could a startup deploy a fiber network in Belgium and challenge the standing duopoly?
2d35b705ad4c.name: SmartFiber — Building a Network

header.description: Could a mere startup deploy a fiber network in Belgium and challenge the standing duopoly?
header.title: Building a Belgian fiber network

2d35b705ad4c.shortDescription: Could a startup deploy a fiber network in Belgium and…

collectionHeaderMetadata.description: Could a mere startup deploy a fiber network in Belgium and challenge the standing duopoly?
collectionHeaderMetadata.title: Building a Belgian fiber network

paragraphs.text: The only business model for fiber that will work to produce the competition, low prices, and world-class data transport we need — certainly in urban areas — is to get local governments involved in overseeing basic, street grid-like “dark” (passive, unlit with electronics) fiber available at a set, wholesale price to a zillion retail providers of access and services. There’s plenty of patient capital sloshing around the US that would be attracted to the steady, reliable returns this kind of investment will return. That investment could be made in the form of private lending or government bonds; the important element is that the resulting basic network be a wholesale facility that any retail actor can use at a reasonable, fair cost.
paragraphs.name: 26ac

paragraphs.text: Look, Google was never going to fix the nation’s high-capacity internet access problem. It’s a problem with several dimensions: In most major urban areas, local cable monopolies dominate completely, selling high-priced, second-rate data services that are inextricably bundled with pay TV packages and unthreatened by competition. In rural areas, former telco monopolies are doing their best to transform themselves into wireless media distribution platforms, cutting off millions of Americans from the modern world by relegating them to third- or fourth-rate unreliable data services. (I keep encountering rural stories of telcos cutting off even crappy DSL service any time anyone stops a subscription; realtors are tearing their hair out trying to ensure that some narrow drip of data will be available to a new buyer of a home. That’s a cataclysm.)
paragraphs.name: 30d8

paragraphs.text: The result: Instead of different wires competing side by side with one another, there would be one great basic facility available neutrally to every form of business. Your ISP could use that fiber in competition with 10 others; your traffic lights could use it to govern congestion; your energy grid could use it to measure and regulate consumption and use of renewables. (Here comes the much-touted Internet of Things, which, without fiber everywhere, is being built on sand.) At the same time, the government would stay out of providing and inventing retail services itself.
paragraphs.name: 6f2c
30d8
paragraphs.text: Look, Google was never going to fix the nation’s high-capacity internet access problem. It’s a problem with several dimensions: In most major urban areas, local cable monopolies dominate completely, selling high-priced, second-rate data services that are inextricably bundled with pay TV packages and unthreatened by competition. In rural areas, former telco monopolies are doing their best to transform themselves into wireless media distribution platforms, cutting off millions of Americans from the modern world by relegating them to third- or fourth-rate unreliable data services. (I keep encountering rural stories of telcos cutting off even crappy DSL service any time anyone stops a subscription; realtors are tearing their hair out trying to ensure that some narrow drip of data will be available to a new buyer of a home. That’s a cataclysm.)

paragraphs.name: 97a9
paragraphs.text: Google’s retreat is all about the bottom line. It wanted an unrealistic rate of return on basic infrastructure. It wanted to see rapid cost declines per subscriber, like the Moore’s Law changes in productivity that have taken place when digital technologists squeeze costs from other legacy businesses.

The only business model for fiber that will work to produce the competition, low prices, and world-class data transport we need — certainly in urban areas — is to get local governments involved in overseeing basic, street grid-like “dark” (passive, unlit with electronics) fiber available at a set, wholesale price to a zillion retail providers of access and services. There’s plenty of patient capital sloshing around the US that would be attracted to the steady, reliable returns this kind of investment will return. That investment could be made in the form of private lending or government bonds; the important element is that the resulting basic network be a wholesale facility that any retail actor can use at a reasonable, fair cost.
paragraphs.name: 26ac

paragraphs.text: The result: Instead of different wires competing side by side with one another, there would be one great basic facility available neutrally to every form of business. Your ISP could use that fiber in competition with 10 others; your traffic lights could use it to govern congestion; your energy grid could use it to measure and regulate consumption and use of renewables. (Here comes the much-touted Internet of Things, which, without fiber everywhere, is being built on sand.) At the same time, the government would stay out of providing and inventing retail services itself.
paragraphs.name: 6f2c

2acf46a007b2.title: This just removes the physical wires from stacking in the overbuild to being the political wires…

paragraphs.text: This just removes the physical wires from stacking in the overbuild to being the political wires and red tape that reduce service to non-usable. ISPs learn very fast that owning your network means you can fix your network and things are good for your customers. Having a middle-man, or worse, a middle-municipality, in the way of doing right by your customers quickly ruins your reputation.
paragraphs.name: add3

b66836f07d9a.title: The state of North Carolina has had at least two competing companies laying fiber far and wide for…

paragraphs.text: The state of North Carolina has had at least two competing companies laying fiber far and wide for about a year. Yards and streets and sidewalks have been drawn on with bright spray paint — yellows, reds, oranges, blues — to mark service lines. Grass gets dug up. Things get damaged unexpectedly. This has been happening repeatedly.
paragraphs.name: f760

da13337d8a1d.title: Infrastructure doesn’t generally make a lot of money — even during the golden age of rail most…

paragraphs.text: Infrastructure doesn’t generally make a lot of money — even during the golden age of rail most companies never made their investors a penny and those that did relied on property development in places that their new routes opened up to make money and not the railway itself.

c0d4a8029058.title: I know there was a government run effort for rural electrification.

paragraphs.text: I know there was a government run effort for rural electrification. My understanding was until the 1930s, AT&T put in most of the country’s telephone infrastructure on it’s own dime, and while the government regulated what they could do, they still paid for all of it. Cable was completely self funded by cable companies. I guess why is it this time no…
No.

And if my company is going to use something, I have to be able to fix…

ec8175048258.title: Susan Crawford, didn’t Utah try to build a municipal fiber network that ended up flopping?

paragraphs.text: Susan Crawford, didn’t Utah try to build a municipal fiber network that ended up flopping? What went wrong there that wouldn’t go wrong elsewhere?

68de5941f0ad.title: Capitalism was built on the idea of competitive pricing and allocation.

paragraphs.text: Capitalism was built on the idea of competitive pricing and allocation. Private firms innovating to make the private lives of humans better. This is something that Google has tried to do a lot with their driverless cars, cheap nexus phones and search engine. I personally think Google fibre will come back to us in the future. Maybe the time wasn’t the right time?
paragraphs.name: 98cd

paragraphs.text: Wires are much more reliable. All of the best, most secure networks in the world are wired. Landlines are often the last network to go down in disasters, because they carry their own low voltage power source. Of course most people under the age of 30 don’t know the importance of landlines as they’ve never been in a disaster that required them.
paragraphs.name: a7ea

d4f414d0b265.title: This is how internet access in Japan works.

paragraphs.text: This is how internet access in Japan works. In Tokyo, the city is divided into a few regions, where each region has a single, highly regulated fiber provider. You pay a nominal (~$10/mo) “fiber access fee”. Then, there are a dozen ISPs who all sell access to the fiber, competing on speed, bandwidth and price. You are free to choose any ISP, and they…
